sections.html:
Zone 2 • Interfaces

Hydration Layers & Interfaces

Where Structure Happens

If you want to understand "structured water," start here: water behaves differently near surfaces.

Interfaces are where ordering happens. Surfaces create the conditions for different water behavior.

What Are Hydration Layers?

Hydration layers are organized water molecules near:

  • Ions — water shells around dissolved ions
  • Surfaces — water ordered against solid materials
  • Membranes — biological boundary layers
  • Macromolecules — protein and DNA hydration

These layers have different properties than bulk water: altered viscosity, different dielectric behavior, slower rotation.

What Surfaces Matter?

Hydrophilic (Water-Loving)

  • Glass, quartz, silica
  • Certain ceramics
  • Nafion membranes (in research)
  • Many biological surfaces

These create stronger ordering effects

Hydrophobic (Water-Repelling)

  • Plastics, Teflon
  • Oils and waxes
  • Some metals

Create different boundary behavior

Practical Implications

  • Container choice matters — glass vs plastic can affect measurements over time
  • Surface area matters — more contact = more interface effects
  • Clean surfaces matter — contamination affects ordering
  • Time matters — interface effects develop over hours

items.question: How thick are hydration layers?
items.answer: Typically a few nanometers to hundreds of nanometers, depending on the surface.

items.question: Can I see hydration layers?
items.answer: Not directly. They're detected through indirect measurements like viscometry or spectroscopy.
